name: Beacons
description: Tacita Dean's Disappearance at Sea explores the romantic isolation of the lighthouse, a rich setting for stories that artists, filmmakers and game-makers have used to examine the threat and freedom of the sea.

key_work.title: Disappearance at Sea
key_work.material_description: Film, 16 mm, projection, colour and sound
key_work.brief_description: Filmed at a lighthouse, this work consists of seven shots that alternate between the rotating lighthouse bulbs and footage looking out to sea. Dean was inspired by the story of Donald Crowhurst, an amateur sailor who died while attempting a solo voyage around the world.

constellations_other.name: Binary images
constellations_other.description: The interiors in Kalonica's Apartment (2021) are rendered in just two colours: white and blue. Like black and white film, this monochromatic art style was first employed due to technological constraints. Many contemporary filmmakers and videogame developers have revisited older techniques like these for artistic effect.

end.title: Cape Forlorn
end.creator_credit: E.A. Dupont, British International Pictures, Victor Kendall and Frank Harvey
end.brief_description: William Kell, the keeper of a lighthouse on a lonely stretch of coastline, marries cabaret dancer Eileen. His young wife, however, goes on to have an affair with Henry Cass, the handsome assistant later taken on by her husband; when she then begins to flirt with a stranger who is rescued from the wreck of a motor-launch, a chain of shocking events is set in motion…

links.description: The romantic and maddening isolation of lighthouses is fertile ground for fictional stories as well as factual ones. One of the earliest narrative films set on one is Cape Forlorn, a 1931 story of passion and betrayal – like The Lighthouse.

end.title: The Phantom Light
end.creator_credit: Michael Powell, Evadne Price, Joan Roy Byford and Gainsborough Pictures
end.brief_description: Criminals pose as ghosts to scare a lighthouse keeper on the Welsh coast, in attempt to distract him. Jim Pearce deliberately maroons himself on the rock along with Alice Bright. When the light is later smashed, Jim reveals that his brother’s ship is the wreckers’ latest target, while Alice is a detective sent to investigate.

links.description: Despite their purpose to save lives, stories set on lighthouses always seem to end in death. Two years after Cape Forlorn, another British film used a lighthouse as the stage for a murder mystery, Michael Powell’s The Phantom Light.

links.description: All these works are British. Robyn Ludwig proposes lighthouses symbolise anxieties and aspirations in Britain during WWII and were critical to defending the country. In The Seventh Survivor, a lighthouse crew saves survivors of torpedoed passenger vessel, but one is a spy for Germany.

links.description: Sometimes the terror in lighthouse stories aren’t symbolic of wartime anxiety. Sometimes they’re just fun. John Carpenter’s cult classic The Fog tells the story of a Californian town swarmed with ghosts who sunk at sea 100 years earlier. Much of the action happens in a lighthouse.

end.title: BioShock
end.brief_description: Set in the Objectivist underwater dystopia of Rapture in the ‘60’s, Bioshock is a first-person shooter with the premise of arming and genetically modifying yourself in order to survive against the city’s resident great minds-turned-maddened anomalies and aid Atlas in his mission to overthrow the city’s cruel ruler, Andrew Ryan.
